1.name: NAME
1.helpText: Enter a descriptive name for this component.

10.name: PAGE_MODE
10.helpText:
Select the page mode for this page.

#LOV_VALUES#

Note that options Modal and Non-Modal Dialog will only be available for selection where the current application theme contains a default Dialog Page Template.

lovValues.helpText: The page is presented as a normal Application Express application page.

The page is presented as a modal dialog.
A modal dialog is an overlay window positioned within the viewport, which remains active and focused until the end user dismisses (closes) it. The underlying page is grayed out and the end user is prevented from interacting with the rest of the page until the dialog is closed.

The page is presented as a non-modal dialog.
A non-modal dialog is an overlay window positioned within the viewport, where the end user can interact with the dialog, and content on the page that launched the dialog. A non-modal dialog can be used when the requested information is not essential to continue, work can continue elsewhere while the window is still open.

100.name: LABEL_ALIGNMENT
100.helpText:
Select the label alignment. Labels can display above, below, or to the left of the item.
When the label displays next to a form element, it occupies its own HTML table cell.
By changing this label alignment, you can control the label's position within that table cell.

101.name: FIELD_TEMPLATE
101.helpText: Select an item template. Item templates enable you to define the user interface attributes as part of a theme and share that definition among many page items.

102.name: FIELD_TABLE_CELL_ATTRIBUTES
102.helpText: Enter any additional attributes used in the HTML table cell that contains this label.

103.name: VALUE_REQUIRED
103.helpText:
If set to Yes and the page item is visible, Application Express automatically performs a NOT NULL validation when the page is submitted.

By defining a message called APEX.PAGE_ITEM_IS_REQUIRED in Shared Components > Text Messages, the predefined error text can be replaced by an application specific error message.

The display location of the message is defined by the application level setting Default error display location.

104.name: GRID_NEW_GRID
104.helpText: Specify whether this component displays in a new grid, or in the same grid as the previous component.

105.name: GRID_NEW_ROW
105.helpText: Specify whether this component displays on the next row after the previous component, or on the same row.

106.name: GRID_COLUMN
106.helpText: Select a specific grid column. Use Automatic to automatically determine the next available grid column where the component displays.

107.name: GRID_NEW_COLUMN
107.helpText: Specify whether this component displays in the next column or in the same column as the previous component.

108.name: GRID_COLUMN_SPAN
108.helpText: Select how many grid columns this component occupies. Use Automatic to balance the available grid columns across all components in the same grid row.

109.name: GRID_ROW_SPAN
109.helpText: Enter how many rows within the HTML table this component occupies. Components are laid out in HTML tables. This attribute determines the value to be used for the ROWSPAN attribute in the table cell for this component.

11.name: PAGE_TEMPLATE
11.helpText: Select a page template to control the appearance of this page. Making a selection here overrides the default page template defined within the current theme.

110.name: GRID_COLUMN_ATTRIBUTES
110.helpText: Enter additional attributes set for the grid column. This value replaces the #ATTRIBUTES# substitution placeholder in the grid layout column template.

111.name: FORMAT_MASK
111.helpText:
Enter a format mask to apply to this component.
You can type in the format mask or pick from the list of predefined format masks, based on a sample representation of how that format mask is displayed.

112.name: FORMAT_MASK_DATE
112.helpText:
Enter a date format mask to apply to this component.
You can type in the format mask or pick from the list of predefined format masks, based on a sample representation of how that format mask displays.
You can also use substitution syntax to reference a dynamic format mask from an application or page item.

113.name: FORMAT_MASK_NUMBER
113.helpText:
Enter a number format mask to apply to this component.
You can type in the format mask or pick from the list of predefined format masks, based on a sample representation of how that format mask displays.
You can also use substitution syntax to reference a format mask from an application or page item.

114.name: NAMED_LOV
114.helpText: Select the name of an exisiting list of values.

115.name: DISPLAY_EXTRA_VALUES
115.helpText:
An item may have a session state value which does not occur in the given list of values definition.
Select whether this list of values displays this extra session state value.
If you choose to not display this extra session state value and there is no matching value in the list of values definition, the first value in the list of values is the selected and displayed value.

116.name: DISPLAY_NULL_VALUE
116.helpText: Specify whether the list of values used for this item displays a NULL value at the top of the list.

117.name: NULL_DISPLAY_VALUE
117.helpText: Enter the text to be displayed within the list NULL option at the top of this list. This value also displays when rendering the item if the value is null. If you do not enter any text, it is displayed as a blank line in the list and a blank item when rendered.

118.name: NULL_RETURN_VALUE
118.helpText: Enter the value to be returned if the NULL value is selected in this list of values. If you do not provide a value, the item value is left as null when the NUll option is selected from this list.

119.name: CASCADING_LOV_PARENT_ITEMS
119.helpText:
Enter page or application items that trigger the refresh of this list of values. For multiple items, separate each item name with a comma. You can type in the name or pick from the list of available items. If you pick from the list, and there is already text entered, then a comma is placed at the end of the existing text, followed by the item name returned from the list.

This list of values is refreshed whenever the value of any of the specified items are changed on this page.

You should use the page item(s) specified in this attribute within the where clause of this list of values SQL Query to restrict the values returned.

For example, if you have page items for Car Make and Model, you could specify Car Make as the Cascading LOV Parent Item within the List of Values definition for Model, and use Car Make within the where clause for that list of values. Then whenever Car Make is changed, the LOV for Model is refreshed, and the list only displays values for the currently selected Car Make.

12.name: STANDARD_TAB_SET
12.helpText: Select a standard tab set used for this page. A standard tab set is associated with a specific page number. You can use standard tabs to link users to a specific page.

120.name: LOV_PAGE_ITEMS_TO_SUBMIT
120.helpText:
Enter page or application items to set into session state when the value of any of the specified Cascading LOV Parent Item(s) change on this page. For multiple items, separate each item name with a comma. You can type in the name or pick from the list of available items. If you pick from the list and there is already text entered, then a comma is placed at the end of the existing text, followed by the item name returned from the list.

You should use the page item(s) specified in this attribute within the where clause of this list of values SQL Query to restrict the values returned.

Note: The page items defined in Cascading LOV Parent Item(s) are automatically transmitted and do not need to be entered into this attribute.

121.name: OPTIMIZE_REFRESH
121.helpText:
Specify under what conditions this list of values is refreshed using AJAX.

If set to Yes the AJAX call to get new values performs only when all Cascading LOV Parent Item(s) are not null. If one item is null, it is assumed that the LOV Query does not return any rows. In such cases, the select list entries are simply cleared in the browser, without doing an AJAX call.

If set to No, the AJAX call always performs. This option is only used if you specifically handle nullable Cascading LOV Parent Item(s) in the where clause of this list of values SQL Query. If nullable page items are not properly handled, unnecessary AJAX calls are executed that never return any rows.

122.name: LOV_SQL
122.examples:
Display department name, set department number
select dname  as d,
       deptno as r
  from dept
 order by 1
122.helpText:
Enter the SQL query definition to populate this list of values. Generally list of value queries are of the form:

select [displayValue],
       [returnValue]
  from ...
 where ...
 order by ...

Each column selected must have a unique name or alias. Oracle recommends using an alias on any column that includes an SQL expression.

123.name: ELEMENT_FIELD_ALIGNMENT
123.helpText: Select the alignment of the item within the HTML table cell that surrounds it.

124.name: ELEMENT_WIDTH
124.helpText: Enter the width of the form element to be used to display this item.

125.name: ELEMENT_MAX_CHARACTERS
125.helpText: Enter the maximum number of characters users can type into this item.

126.name: ELEMENT_HEIGHT
126.helpText: Enter the height (approximate number of rows) for textareas, shuttles, multi select lists, and any plug-in Item types that support the Has Height Attribute attribute.

127.name: ELEMENT_VALUE_PLACEHOLDER
127.helpText:
Enter hint text displayed in this item when no value for that item is entered. Once any text is entered into the item, the hint is removed.

This placeholder attribute specifies a short hint that can be used to describe the expected value of a page item. Such hints are useful for providing a sample value, or an example of the expected format, or instructions such as: Search on title, description, and tag. For accessibility reasons, this attribute should not be used as an alternative to a well defined, meaningful label.

Attention: This is a HTML5 feature and only works in modern browsers! Older browsers do not display the text entered into this attribute.

128.name: ADVANCED_CSS_CLASSES
128.examples:
Add the CSS classes articlenumber and highlight to the HTML tag of the component
articlenumber highlight
128.helpText: Enter additional space delimited CSS classes to be included in the component.

129.name: CUSTOM_ATTRIBUTES
129.helpText:
Enter additional space delimited attributes to be included in the item tag.
For the HTML CLASS attribute, Oracle recommends using the dedicated CSS Classes attribute.

13.name: TITLE
13.helpText: Enter the page title. The page title is displayed in the title bar of the browser window.

130.name: ELEMENT_OPTION_HTML_ATTRIBUTES
130.helpText: Enter additional space-delimited attributes for the HTML table cell used to display each individual option in a radio group or set of check boxes.

131.name: ELEMENT_PRE_TEXT
131.helpText:
Enter additional attributes displayed before the HTML table cell that displays each individual option in a radio group or set of check boxes. You can include HTML, JavaScript, and shortcuts.

You can reference the following substitution strings:

#CURRENT_FORM_ELEMENT#
Obtains the name of the HTML form element that this page item is associated with.
#CURRENT_ITEM_NAME#
Obtains the name of the current page item.

132.name: ELEMENT_POST_TEXT
132.helpText:
Enter additional attributes displayed after the HTML table cell that displays each individual option in a radio group or set of check boxes. You can include HTML, JavaScript, and shortcuts.

You can reference the following substitution strings:

#CURRENT_FORM_ELEMENT#
Obtains the name of the HTML form element that this page item is associated with.
#CURRENT_ITEM_NAME#
Obtains the name of the current page item.

133.name: SOURCE_USED
133.helpText:
Select which value takes precedence, the value from session state or the item source value.

For items with the source type Database Column, select Always, replacing any existing value in session state unless you do not want the associated row fetch operation to populate the item if the page branches back to itself. For other source types you must decide, based on how the page is used, whether the previously sourced value is displayed, or if the source type is applied anew for each page view.

lovValues.d: Always, replacing any existing value in session state
Only when current value in session state is null

134.name: SOURCE_TYPE
134.helpText: Select the source type the value of this item is based on.

lovValues.helpText: Set to the text entered into Static Value.
Set to the column value entered in Database Column, that is retrieved from a built-in fetch row process.
Set to the value held in session state for the Item selected.
Set to the first value returned from the SQL Query entered.
Set to a single colon separated value, which concatenates each row value, returned from the SQL Query entered.
Set to the value that results from executing the PL/SQL Expression entered.
Set to the value returned from the PL/SQL Function Body entered.
Set to the value of the Preference entered.
Set to null.

135.name: SOURCE_STATIC_VALUE
135.helpText: Enter the static value used as the source for this item value.

136.name: SOURCE_QUERY
136.helpText: Enter the SQL Query used as the source for this item value. If more than one row is returned then the value of the first row is used.

137.name: SOURCE_QUERY_COLON
137.helpText: Enter the SQL Query that returns one or more rows to be used as the source for this item value. If the result contains multiple rows then the value from each row is formed into a single colon delimited value.

138.name: SOURCE_ITEM
138.helpText:
Enter the page or application item used as the source for this item value.
You can type in the name or pick from the list of available items.

139.name: SOURCE_PLSQL_EXPRESSION
139.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL expression that produces a value used as the source for this item value.

14.name: CURSOR_FOCUS
14.helpText: Specify whether the cursor is focussed when first entering the page.

lovValues.helpText: The cursor focus is placed on the first field on the page using JavaScript, generated by the Application Express engine.

The cursor is not focussed and no JavaScript is generated.
Select this option if the generated JavaScript conflicts with custom JavaScript.

140.name: SOURCE_PLSQL_FUNCTION_BODY
140.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL function body that returns a value used as the source for this item value.

141.name: SOURCE_DB_COLUMN
141.helpText:
Enter the case sensitive database column name used as the source for this item value.

This column must exist in the table specified within the built-in fetch row process defined on this page. An error is raised, and the page is not loaded, if the database column name does not exist in the referenced table. Similarly, if there is no built-in fetch row process defined and there is an item with a source type of Database Column, then an error is raised, and the page is not loaded when trying to render the page.

142.name: SOURCE_PREFERENCE
142.helpText: Enter the User Preference to be used as the source for this item value.

143.name: POST_CALCULATION_COMPUTATION
143.helpText:
Enter a PL/SQL expression to refine the value of the item.

For example, if this item is named P1_X, you could use post calculation expressions such as UPPER(:P1_X), INITCAP(:P2_Y), MIN(:P1_X, :P2_Y - 200), NVL(:P1_X, :P2_Y), or a function call such as my_func(:P1_X) to set the final value of the item. Note that these examples demonstrate that the expressions can reference the current item, or they may reference any other item in session state.

144.name: MAINTAIN_SESSION_STATE
144.helpText: Select how session state is maintained. Select Per session to maintain session state per session. Select Per user to maintain session state for a user across sessions.

145.name: DEFAULT_VALUE_TYPE
145.helpText: Select a default value type for this item.

146.name: DEFAULT_VALUE_STATIC_TEXT
146.helpText: Specify a default value for this item. The default value is used when the item's value is not derived from session state and when the source value is null.

147.name: DEFAULT_VALUE_PLSQL_FUNC_BODY
147.helpText: Enter the PL/SQL function body which returns the value for this item.

148.name: DEFAULT_VALUE_PLSQL_EXPRESSION
148.helpText: Enter the PL/SQL expression that produces the value for this item.

149.name: SHOW_QUICK_PICKS
149.helpText:
Specify whether quick picks is displayed for this page item. Quick picks enables users to select predefined values with just one click, rather than typing in text or selecting from a list of available options.

You should specify quick picks when there is a relatively small, discrete set of common input values. There is a maximum of ten quick picks that can be defined for an item. Such user aids are especially useful when defined for an item that has a lengthy select list of available values.

15.name: JS_FILE_URLS
15.examples:
Standard file reference
/myjs/main.js
Standard file reference which loads the minified file main.min.js from /myjs/minified/ for regular page views and main.js from /myjs/ in debug mode.
/myjs/#MIN_DIRECTORY#main#MIN#.js
Conditional file for Internet Explorer
[if IE]/myjs/ie.js
File reference using a query string in the URL referencing the application version, such that when the application is upgraded (and the version is incremented), the browser is instructed to always load the new file and ignore any previously cached files.
/myjs/main.js?version=#APP_VERSION#
15.helpText:
Enter JavaScript file URLs for code loaded on this page. Each URL must be written on a new line. If you provide a minified version of your file you can use the substitution string #MIN# to include .min or #MIN_DIRECTORY# to include minified/ in your file URL for a regular page view and an empty string if the page is viewed in debug mode. You also have access to the substitution string #APP_VERSION# if you want to include the application's version in the file URL.

JavaScript file URLs you enter here replaces the #PAGE_JAVASCRIPT# substitution string in the page template.

Note: You do not need to include opening or closing script tags. Just specify the URL.

150.name: QUICK_PICK_LINK_ATTRIBUTES
150.helpText: Enter HTML attributes that are associated with the display of each Quick Pick link.

151.name: QUICK_PICK_LABEL_01
151.helpText: Enter the label for the first Quick Pick. This label is the text the end user of the application sees.

152.name: QUICK_PICK_VALUE_01
152.helpText: Enter the value associated with the first Quick Pick. This value replaces the existing item value when the user clicks this quick pick.

153.name: QUICK_PICK_LABEL_02
153.helpText: Enter the label for the second Quick Pick. This label is the text the end user of the application sees.

154.name: QUICK_PICK_VALUE_02
154.helpText: Enter the value associated with the second Quick Pick. This value replaces the existing item value when the user clicks this quick pick.

155.name: QUICK_PICK_LABEL_03
155.helpText: Enter the label for the third Quick Pick. This label is the text the end user of the application sees.

156.name: QUICK_PICK_VALUE_03
156.helpText: Enter the value associated with the third Quick Pick. This value replaces the existing item value when the user clicks this quick pick.

157.name: QUICK_PICK_LABEL_04
157.helpText: Enter the label for the forth Quick Pick. This label is the text the end user of the application sees.

158.name: QUICK_PICK_VALUE_04
158.helpText: Enter the value associated with the forth Quick Pick. This value replaces the existing item value when the user clicks this quick pick.

159.name: QUICK_PICK_LABEL_05
159.helpText: Enter the label for the fifth Quick Pick. This label is the text the end user of the application sees.

16.name: JS_FUNCTION_AND_GLOBAL_VARIABLE_DECLARATION
16.helpText:
Enter JavaScript code such as functions or global variable declarations referenced on this page. To reference a shortcut, use "SHORTCUTNAME". If the same JavaScript is required on multiple pages, consider putting the code into an external JavaScript file to avoid duplication and to leverage browser caching of static files.

Code you enter here replaces the #PAGE_JAVASCRIPT# substitution string in the page template.

Note: You do not need to include opening or closing script tags. Just include the JavaScript code.

160.name: QUICK_PICK_VALUE_05
160.helpText: Enter the value associated with the fifth Quick Pick. This value replaces the existing item value when the user clicks this quick pick.

161.name: QUICK_PICK_LABEL_06
161.helpText: Enter the label for the sixth Quick Pick. This label is the text the end user of the application sees.

162.name: QUICK_PICK_VALUE_06
162.helpText: Enter the value associated with the sixth Quick Pick. This value replaces the existing item value when the user clicks this quick pick.

163.name: QUICK_PICK_LABEL_07
163.helpText: Enter the label for the seventh Quick Pick. This label is the text the end user of the application sees.

164.name: QUICK_PICK_VALUE_07
164.helpText: Enter the value associated with the seventh Quick Pick. This value replaces the existing item value when the user clicks this quick pick.

165.name: QUICK_PICK_LABEL_08
165.helpText: Enter the label for the eighth Quick Pick. This label is the text the end user of the application sees.

166.name: QUICK_PICK_VALUE_08
166.helpText: Enter the value associated with the eighth Quick Pick. This value replaces the existing item value when the user clicks this quick pick.

167.name: QUICK_PICK_LABEL_09
167.helpText: Enter the label for the ninth Quick Pick. This label is the text the end user of the application sees.

168.name: QUICK_PICK_VALUE_09
168.helpText: Enter the value associated with the ninth Quick Pick. This value replaces the existing item value when the user clicks this quick pick.

169.name: QUICK_PICK_LABEL_10
169.helpText: Enter the label for the tenth Quick Pick. This label is the text the end user of the application sees.

17.name: JS_EXECUTE_WHEN_PAGE_LOADS
17.helpText:
Enter JavaScript code to execute when the page loads. The code is executed after the JavaScript code generated by Oracle Application Express.

Code you enter here replaces the #GENERATED_JAVASCRIPT# substitution string in the page template.

Note: You do not need to add any opening or closing script tags, just the JavaScript code.

170.name: QUICK_PICK_VALUE_10
170.helpText: Enter the value associated with the tenth Quick Pick. This value replaces the existing item value when the user clicks this quick pick.

171.name: READ_ONLY_HTML_ATTRIBUTES
171.helpText: Enter attributes included in the item HTML table cell tag, <td>, when displayed in read only mode.

172.name: SESSION_STATE_PROTECTION
172.helpText: Select a Session State Protection level.

lovValues.helpText: The item can be set by passing the item in a URL or in a form. No checksum is required in the URL.
The item can be set by passing the item in a URL that includes a checksum specific to the the workspace and application.
The item can be set by passing the item in a URL that includes a checksum specific to the the workspace, application and user.
The item can be set by passing the item in a URL that includes a checksum specific to the the session.

lovValues.d: Restricted - May not be set from browser
lovValues.helpText:
The item can not be altered using the URL or POSTDATA. Select this option to restrict what can set the item value to internal processes, computations, and so on. This attribute only applies to items that are not used as data entry items and is always observed, even if Session State Protection is disabled. Use this attribute for page or application items that have the following Display As types:
  • Display Only (Save State=No)
  • Text Field (Disabled, does not save state)

173.name: ENCRYPT_SESSION_STATE
173.prompt: Store value encrypted in session state
173.helpText:
Specify whether to encrypt this item when stored in session state. If the contents of an item contain sensitive data, then you should encrypt the value when it is stored in the Application Express session state management tables. Otherwise, anyone with rights to read the Application Express meta data tables could potentially write a query to extract this sensitive data.

Note: Only values up to 4000 bytes in length can be encrypted. Attempts to encrypt values longer than 4000 bytes produce an error message.

174.name: ESCAPE_SPECIAL_CHARACTERS
174.helpText: To prevent Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks, always set this attribute to Yes. If you need to render HTML tags stored in the page item or in the entries of a list of values, you can set this flag to No. In such cases, you should take additional precautions to ensure any user input to such fields are properly escaped when entered and before saving.

175.name: RESTRICTED_CHARACTERS
175.helpText:
Select how to restrict the characters that can be saved in session state. Application Express displays an error message if a user tries to save data that does not conform to the selected character restriction.

Restricting the characters hardens application security and is a possible counter measure to cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.

lovValues.helpText: Only characters a-z, A-Z, 0-9 and space can be saved.
Reserved HTML characters can NOT be saved.
The following characters: &, <, >, ", /, ;, ",", *, |, =, % and "--" (PL/SQL comment) can NOT be saved.
The following characters: &, <, >, ", /, ;, ",", *, |, =, %, "--", and new line characters can NOT be saved.

176.name: BUTTON_NAME
176.helpText:
Enter the name used to identify this button within susbsequent page processing. When the page is submitted, by pressing this button, the REQUEST value is set to the name entered.

Button name does not have to be unique, for buttons on the same page or in the same region. You can define multiple buttons with the same button name, which sets the same REQUEST value when pressed. This is useful for defining buttons with different Button Labels or conditions, that need to execute the same page processing, by simply evaluating the common REQUEST value.

If you name the button FLOW_RESET_BUTTON then the button resets the current page without doing a page submit.

177.name: BUTTON_LABEL
177.helpText: If the button is text, enter the text to be displayed on the button. If the button is an image, then this text becomes the ALT text for the image.

178.name: BUTTON_POSITION
178.helpText:
Select the position to display this button. The available template default positions identify the display position within the page template. Using REGION_TEMPLATE button positions enables you to define a button position within a region template. Buttons using REGION_TEMPLATE positions only be display if:

  1. The region template contains the position. For example #EDIT# is required to show a button in the REGION_TEMPLATE_EDIT position.
  2. The button is part of a region.

Buttons using REGION_TEMPLATE positions take precedence over static region template defined links.

179.name: HORIZONTAL_ALIGNMENT
179.helpText: Select the horizontal alignment for this button within the specified template position.

18.name: INCLUDE_STANDARD_JAVASCRIPT_AND_CSS
18.helpText:
Oracle Application Express typically requires specific JavaScript and CSS files. For some applications, such as mobile applications, you may want to suppress the inclusion of these files on the page.

To Include the standard Application Express and JavaScript files select Yes. Selecting No suppresses the inclusion of these files in the HTML Header.

Suppressing inclusion of these files can have adverse effects on an application and may cause it to break. Therefore, disabling this attribute is only recommended for advanced developers.

180.name: STATIC_ID
180.helpText: Enter the static ID for this component. If defined, this ID can be useful if developing custom JavaScript behavior for the component.

182.name: BUTTON_TEMPLATE
182.helpText:
Select which template controls the display of this button. If you do not want to use a button template, change the button template to null.

Button templates are defined on the templates page. You must have at least one button template defined to use button templates.

183.name: BUTTON_IS_HOT
183.helpText: Select whether to use the Normal or Hot button template when rendering this button.

187.name: BUTTON_TARGET
187.helpText: Click the Target to invoke a modal dialog. You can enter the target to be called when this button is clicked. Only enter a target for buttons that should not invoke page processing when clicked (for example, a Cancel button).

188.name: BUTTON_EXECUTE_VALIDATIONS
188.helpText:
If the page is submitted and this attribute is set to Yes, all validations defined for the page and also the built-in validations are executed (such as required, valid number or valid date).

If set to No, none of the defined validations nor the built-in validations are executed. If you want a specific validation to execute independent of this setting, modify the validation and set the validation attribute Always Execute to Yes.

This attribute is particularly useful for buttons such as Delete or Cancel where the majority of validations should not be executed. Users should generally not be stopped from performing such actions if an item is null or of the wrong type. However, if actions, such as Delete, should only be performed by authorized users it is important to set the corresponding validation attribute Always Execute to Yes, or ensure there is an appropriate condition defined on the button itself so that the button is only displayed to authorized users.

189.name: BUTTON_DATABASE_ACTION
189.helpText: Select the type of SQL operation that clicking this button performs. This selection is used to trigger the specified database action within built-in Automatic Row Processing (DML). If you do not select a type, database processing executes based on the REQUEST value, which is set based on the Button Name defined for this button.

19.name: HTML_HEADER
19.helpText:
Enter text to replace the #HEAD# substitution string in the page template header. The values entered here are inserted after the HTML <head> tag. Use this page attribute to add page specific meta tags.

Note: JavaScript code or Cascading Style Sheets should be added to the dedicated JavaScript and CSS attributes.

190.name: PARENT_REGION
190.helpText: Select the parent region to which this region belongs. If a parent region is selected then this region is rendered completely inside the parent region.

191.name: REGION_POSITION
191.helpText: Select the template position used to display this region. The selections available are derived from the appropriate template positions defined within the current theme, for the page's user interface.

192.name: PROCESS_POINT
192.helpText: Select the point at which this process is executed.

193.name: REGION_SQL
193.helpText: Enter the SQL source for this component.

194.name: REGION_PLAIN
194.helpText: Enter the text source for this component.

195.name: DIALOG_HEIGHT
195.helpText: Enter the height of the dialog, in pixels, for example, 500. The substitution string #DIALOG_HEIGHT# in the dialog initialization code of the page template is replaced with the value entered.

198.name: PLSQL_CODE
198.helpText: Enter the PL/SQL source utilized within this authentication scheme.

20.name: PAGE_HTML_BODY_ATTRIBUTE
20.helpText: Enter text substituted in for your page template's #ONLOAD# substitution string. To use this feature, your page template must include the #ONLOAD# substitution string.

21.name: HEADER_TEXT
21.helpText: Enter text or HTML you want to appear immediately following the page header and before the body content.

213.name: EXCLUDE_TITLE_FROM_TRANSLATION
213.helpText: Specify whether you want to exclude this title from translation. This attribute has no effect, except when translating the application into another language.

214.name: REGION_HTML_CODE
214.helpText: Enter the region source or content, depending on the Region Type selected.

215.name: SOURCE_PAGE_ITEMS_TO_SUBMIT
215.helpText:
Enter page or application items to be set into session state when the region is refreshed by a partial page refresh. For multiple items, separate each item name with a comma. You can type in the name or pick from the list of available items. If you pick from the list and there is already text entered, then a comma is placed at the end of the existing text, followed by the item name returned from the list.

The region can be refreshed with partial page refresh either during pagination, if Enable Partial Page Refresh is set to Yes), or with the Refresh action within a Dynamic Action.

These page items can then be used in the where condition of the Region Source SQL Query to restrict the query result.

216.name: SCHEMA_OVERRIDE_ITEM
216.helpText: Enter the page or application item to be used as the overriding parsing schema.  This is for internal applications only.

218.name: ITEM_DISPLAY_POSITION
218.helpText: Specify where page items display in relation to the main region content.

219.name: REGION_DISPLAY_SELECTOR
219.helpText:
Specify Yes if you want this region included in the Region Display Selector. This attribute is only utilized if a region type of Region Display Selector is defined and viewable on the page.

When a user clicks on a region name, included in the Region Display Selector, only the selected region shows and all other listed regions are hidden. The first entry within the Region Display Selector is Show All, which enables the user to show all of the available regions rather than only the previously selected region.

If a region is not displayable, based on the region conditions, then it is not included in the lists of regions within the Region Display Selector.

22.name: BODY_HEADER
22.helpText: Enter text or HTML you want to appear before regions that display on the running page. Text you enter here appears before the page template #BODY# substitution string.

220.name: REGION_IMAGE
220.helpText: Enter a reference to an image that displays in the upper left of the region. There is no control over the table tag used to display this image.

221.name: IMAGE_TAG_ATTRIBUTES
221.helpText:
Enter image tag attributes included in the image HTML. This can be used for attributes such as height, width or image ALT text (if the image is non-decorative).

Note: If no ALT is defined in the image tag attributes, Application Express defaults to rendering the image as a decorative image, for example with an empty ALT tag.

222.name: CACHE_MODE
222.helpText: Select how the Application Express engine can cache HTML text on the server side. If caching can be used, it emits the cached result instead of computing it again. This cuts down on expensive computation time on the server. This feature is unrelated to the browser's caching capabilities.

lovValues.helpText: Content is not cached and computed for each request.
Content is cached and utilized by all users.
Content is cached specifically for each user.
Content is cached specifically for each session.

223.name: CUSTOMIZABLE
223.helpText: Select whether display attributes in this region can be customized by the user.

lovValues.d: Customizable and Not Shown By Default

224.name: CUSTOMIZED_OPTION_NAME
224.helpText:
Enter the label for the link that displays under this region, which provides access to the region customization page.
This label only displays for regions that are customizable.

225.name: REGION_FUNCTION_RETURNING_SQL
225.prompt: PL/SQL Function Body returning SQL Query
225.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL Function that returns a SQL query that is used as the basis for this region.

226.name: BRANCH_TYPE
226.helpText:
Select the type of page branch to perform.

Redirect branches
Application Express returns the new page or URL to the browser, which performs a new request before showing the resultant page. The major advantage is that the end users can refresh the page without losing context, as the browser address contains the full page URL. The disadvantage is that the browser performs an additional request to show the page.
Show Only branches
Application Express immediately renders the new page as part of the current page processing, without performing another request. This has the advantage that the browser does not have to perform an additional request. The major disadvantage is that the browser address will be wwv_flow.accept. If the end users refreshes the page the browser will ask to resend the data, as the browser address is not a full page URL.

Oracle recommends that you select Redirect branches to provide a better end user experience.

227.name: BRANCH_POINT
227.helpText: Select the point in the processing at which this branch action is considered.

228.name: TARGET
228.helpText: Click the Target to invoke a modal dialog. You can enter the target that is called when this branch is invoked.

229.name: BRANCH_PAGE_NUMBER
229.helpText: Enter the page to which this branch is redirected.

23.name: FOOTER_TEXT
23.helpText: Enter text or HTML that appears before the page template footer.

230.name: BRANCH_ITEM
230.helpText:
Enter the page or application item containing a page number or URL to redirect to.
This item can be set by the calling page, or by a process when the page first loads.
Specifying an item provides an easy way to dynamically set the branch for pages that are called from many other pages.

231.name: BRANCH_PLSQL_FUNCTION_BODY
231.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL Function that returns a page number or URL to redirect to.

232.name: BRANCH_PLSQL
232.helpText: Enter the PL/SQL code executed by the branch. This PL/SQL procedure is responsible for invoking the necessary URL.

233.name: SAVE_STATE_BEFORE_BRANCH
233.helpText: Specify whether values in session state are saved to the database before the branch executes. It is important to set this attribute to Yes if you are navigating to a different application that needs to access the session state values from this application.

234.name: WHEN_BUTTON_PRESSED
234.helpText: If you want this page processing component to execute only when the specified button is clicked, select a button from the list. You can incorporate this button condition with other conditions to further refine when this page processing component executes.

24.name: AUTHORIZATION_SCHEME
24.helpText: Select an authorization scheme to control this component. The authorization must evaluate to TRUE in order for this component to be rendered or executed.

245.name: ALWAYS_EXECUTE
245.helpText:
Specify whether this validation is always executed. If set to Yes, this validation is always evaluated, irrespective of the Execute Validations setting defined against the button that submitted the page. If set to No, this validation is only evaluated if the triggering button has an Execute Validations setting of Yes.

Note: This validation must also comply with the conditions specified before being evaluated.

246.name: ERROR_MESSAGE_DISPLAY_LOCATION
246.helpText: Select where the error message displays for this validation. Validation error messages display on a separate error page, or inline with the existing page. Inline error messages display underneath the Associated Item label and/or in a Notification area, defined as part of the page template.

lovValues.d: Inline with Field and in Notification

247.name: ASSOCIATED_ITEM
247.helpText: Select the item where this validation error message displays. If you select an item and the Error message display location includes "Inline with Field", the error message displays underneath the label of the specified item. If the Error message display location does not include "Inline with Field", this attribute has no impact on the display of the error message.

248.name: ASSOCIATED_COLUMN
248.helpText: Select the column associated with this page processing component.

249.name: EXECUTION_SCOPE
249.helpText: Select the execution scope for this Tabular Form validation. Select For Created and Modified Rows, if you want this validation to be evaluated for new and updated rows in your Tabular Form. If you want your validation to be evaluated for every submitted row, select All Submitted Rows.

25.name: PAGE_AUTHENTICATION
25.helpText:
Specify whether this page is public or requires authentication.
If a page is identified as public, the page can be viewed by any user who accesses the page.
This attribute only applies if the application uses SCHEME authentication.
The application's page sentry function may access this page attribute to identify pages that do not require prior authentication to view.
The implementation of the authentication scheme's page sentry function determines whether this attribute has any effect.

250.name: EXECUTE_CONDITION
250.helpText: Specify how many times this Tabular Form validation is executed. If you refer to Columns in your condition, you must specify For Each Row in order for the condition to be evaluated for each row of the Tabular Form. Otherwise, set to Once to evaluate the validations one time.

251.name: VALIDATION_REGION
251.helpText: Select the associated region for this Tabular Form validation.

252.name: BUTTON_ACTION
252.helpText: Select the action to be performed when this button is clicked.

lovValues.helpText: Submit the current page with a REQUEST value equal to the Button Name.

lovValues.d: Redirect to Page in this Application
lovValues.helpText: Redirect to a page in the current application, with optional additional attributes for resetting pagination, setting the request value, clearing cache and setting item values, on the target page.

lovValues.d: Redirect to Page in a different Application
lovValues.helpText: Redirect to a page in a different application, with optional additional attributes for resetting pagination, setting the request value, clearing cache and setting item values, on the target page.
Redirect to the target URL you specify.
Does not submit the page or redirect to another page. Instead the button's behavior is defined by a Dynamic Action.
Reset the page by performing a complete page refresh, not a Partial Page Refresh (PPR).
Redirect to the next page.
Redirect to the previous page.

253.name: USER_INTERFACE
253.helpText: Shows the user interface for this page.

254.name: DIALOG_TEMPLATE
254.helpText: Select a dialog template to control the appearance of this page. Making a selection here overrides the default dialog template defined within the current theme.

255.name: OVERWRITE_NAVIGATION_LIST
255.helpText: Specify whether the navigation menu list defined on User Interface level is overwritten.

256.name: NAVIGATION_LIST
256.helpText: Select the navigation menu list utilized for navigation on this page.

257.name: NAVIGATION_LIST_TEMPLATE
257.helpText: Select the navigation menu list template utilized with the navigation menu list on this page.

26.name: DEEP_LINKING
26.helpText:
Select how external URL requests to this page are handled.
Page requests from within this application to this page, are not considered deep linking, and are not governed by this attribute's setting.

lovValues.helpText:
If this page is specified as the target page in a URL, it ultimately redirects to this page.
If the user is not already authenticated and the page is not public, then the user is prompted to login. After successfully logging into the application, the user is redirected to this page.
If the URL does not contain a valid session ID, Application Express starts a new session and redirects the user to the application home page, rather than to this page.

266.name: INCLUDE_SEARCH_BAR
266.helpText:
A search bar is displayed above the report. If you include the search bar, you can also fully customize which functions to display.

The search bar can include the following components:
Search Field
Displays a text field in the search bar used to enter search criteria.
Finder Drop Down
Embedded within the Search Field, displays a drop down list of displayed columns. If a column is selected then the search is only performed against the values in the selected column.
Reports Select List
Displays a list of all available reports for the user, including primary, alternate, public and private reports. This list is only displayed if a report, other than the primary report, is accessible to the user.
Rows Per Page Selector
Displays a select list used to select the number of rows to display per page.
Actions Menu
Displays the Actions menu button, which generally includes a comprehensive set of options. These options enables the end user to customize the report based upon the functions you make available.

267.name: COLUMN_NAME
267.helpText: Enter the column name for this report column.

268.name: COLUMN_TYPE
268.helpText: Enter the data type for the report column.

269.name: IR_COLUMN_GROUP
269.helpText: Select the group for this column. Groups are used to display columns in logical groups in the Single Row View.

27.name: PAGE_ACCESS_PROTECTION
27.helpText: Select what type of session state protection is implemented for this page.

lovValues.helpText: The page may be requested using a URL, with or without session state arguments, and without having to have a checksum.

If Request, Clear Cache, or Name/Value Pair arguments appear in the URL, a checksum must also be provided.
The checksum type must be compatible with the most stringent Session State Protection attribute of all the items passed as arguments.
A URL may be used to request the page, but the URL can not contain Request, Clear Cache, or Name/Value Pair arguments.

The page may not be accessed using a URL.
However, the page may be the target of a Branch to Page branch type, as this does not perform a URL redirect.

271.name: IR_COLUMN_DISPLAY_TYPE
271.helpText: Select the relevant column display type to define how column values are displayed.

lovValues.helpText: Displays the column value.

lovValues.d: Plain Text (based on List of Values)
lovValues.helpText: Displays the value returned from the list of values specified.
Displays the column as a link.
Displays the column as an image.
Displays the column as a link to download the file.
Displays the column as a percentage graph. The value retrieved must be between 0 and 100.
Displayes the column value, after removing HTML tags and escaping special characters.
Does not display the column, but it is referenceable.

272.name: COLUMN_HEADING
272.helpText: Enter the report column heading text.

273.name: SYNC_FORM_LABEL
273.helpText: Specify this attribute if you want to use the column heading text as the label in the Detail View.

274.name: SINGLE_ROW_VIEW_LABEL
274.helpText: Enter the column label to use in the Single Row View.

275.name: HEADING_ALIGNMENT
275.helpText: Select the heading alignment. Note that your alignment selection must be supported by the selected report template.

276.name: COLUMN_ALIGNMENT
276.helpText: Select the column display alignment. Note that your alignment selection must be supported by the selected report template.

277.name: ALLOW_USERS_TO_HIDE
277.helpText: Specify whether end users can hide this column.

278.name: ALLOW_USERS_TO_SORT
278.helpText: Specify whether end users can sort this column.

279.name: ALLOW_USERS_TO_FILTER
279.helpText: Specify whether end users can filter this column.

28.name: ALLOW_DUPLICATE_PAGE_SUBMISSIONS
28.helpText:
Select whether the end user may submit the same page more than once.
Use this feature to avoid duplicate inserts into the same table.
This can happen when an end user clicks the browser's back button and then submits the page again, or if the end user clicks the browser's reload button.

lovValues.d: No - Prevent page from being re-posted
Yes - Enable page to be re-posted

280.name: ALLOW_USERS_TO_HIGHLIGHT
280.helpText: Specify whether end users can highlight this column.

281.name: ALLOW_USERS_TO_CONTROL_BREAK
281.helpText: Specify whether end users can utilize this column in a control break.

282.name: ALLOW_USERS_TO_AGGREGATE
282.helpText: Specify whether end users can aggregate this column.

283.name: ALLOW_USERS_TO_COMPUTE
283.helpText: Specify whether end users can utilize this column in a computational column they define.

284.name: ALLOW_USERS_TO_CHART
284.helpText: Specify whether end users can use this column within a chart.

285.name: ALLOW_USERS_TO_GROUP_BY
285.helpText: Specify whether end users can group by this column.

286.name: IR_COLUMN_FILTER_TYPE
286.helpText: Select how to derive the filters provided in the report column drop down list.

lovValues.helpText: There is no column filter provided for this report.
STRING and NUMBER columns derive the list of values from distinct column values. DATE columns derive the list of values from predefined date ranges.

lovValues.d: Use Defined List of Values to Filter Exact Match
lovValues.helpText: Derive the list of values from a defined list of values SQL query to create an equal match filter.

lovValues.d: Use Defined List of Values to Filter Word Contains
lovValues.helpText: Derive the list of values from a defined list of values SQL query to create a contains filter.

lovValues.d: Use Named List of Values to Filter Exact Match
lovValues.helpText: Derive the list of values from the named list of values to create an equal filter.

lovValues.d: Use Named List of Values to Filter Word Contains
lovValues.helpText: Derive the list of values from the named list of values to create a contains filter.

288.name: REPORT_FILTER_DATE_RANGES
288.helpText:
Select the list of values date restrictions.
For date columns, the list of values can display past time, future time, or both in the filter for the report column drop down list.

289.name: HTML_EXPRESSION
289.examples:
Change the background and text colors
<span style="background-color:yellow; color:red;">#EMPLOYEE_STATUS#</span>
Use Heading 2
<h2>#EMPLOYEE_NAME#</h2>
Use a dynamic class from the SQL query
<span class="#COLUMN_CLASS#">#EMPLOYEE_STATUS#</span>

The #COLUMN_CLASS# and #EMPLOYEE_STATUS# substitutions in this example are columns selected in the report SQL query.
Show an image, and a tooltip on hover
<img src="#IMAGE_NAME#" title="#EMPLOYEE_NAME#">
289.helpText: Specify HTML expressions to be shown in this column. Use #COLUMN# syntax to show column values in HTML.

29.name: ON_DUPLICATE_PAGE_SUBMISSIONS_GO_TO_THIS_URL
29.prompt: On duplicate page submissions go to this URL
29.helpText: Enter a URL target for when an end user attempts to perform a second page submission. Application Express displays an error message and a link to this URL to enable the user to continue.

290.name: LINK_TEXT
290.helpText: Enter the HTML text to be shown as a link. Use an image tag to display images, or pick from the list of default images.

291.name: LINK_ATTRIBUTES
291.examples:
Open the link in a new window
target="_blank"
Show a tooltip on hover
title="Click to edit"
291.helpText: Specify additional column link attributes to be included in the <a href=...> tag, including link target, classes or styles.

292.name: IR_PAGINATION_TYPE
292.helpText:
Select the pagination type for this report. Often only a certain number of rows of a report display on a page. In order to include additional rows, the application end user must to navigate to the next page of the report.

Pagination provides the end user with information about the number of rows and the current position within the result set.

Pagination can be shown above or below the report (or both) and can be positioned on the left or right.

lovValues.d: Row Ranges X to Y of Z

293.name: PAGINATION_DISPLAY_POSITION
293.helpText: Select where the report pagination displays.

294.name: SHOW_NULL_VALUES_AS
294.helpText: Enter the text you want to display for null columns.

295.name: MAXIMUM_ROW_COUNT
295.helpText: Enter the maximum number of rows to query. The number of rows you query can impact performance. Querying fewer rows can improve performance and querying thousands of rows can degrade performance.

297.name: WHEN_NO_DATA_FOUND_MESSAGE
297.helpText: Enter a text message to display if the query does not return any rows.

30.name: FORM_AUTO_COMPLETE
30.helpText:
Specify whether auto-complete is disabled for this page. A value of On has no effect on this page. A value of Off generates the following HTML in the FORM tag: 
autocomplete="off"

302.name: SAVE_PUBLIC_REPORT_AUTHORIZATION
302.helpText:
Select an authorization scheme to restrict who can save public report definitions.
To enable an end user to save a public report, this authorization scheme must evaluate to TRUE.
If no authorization scheme is provided then reports may be saved by any user.

306.name: SEARCH_BUTTON_LABEL
306.helpText: Enter the text for the search button label.

307.name: MAXIMUM_ROWS_PER_PAGE
307.helpText: Enter the maximum number to display in the Rows Per Page selector.

308.name: DOWNLOAD_FORMATS
308.helpText:
Check which download formats users can utilize to download the currently displayed columns.

Email is only be available for authenticated users and requires an administrator configure SMTP configuration within the Application Express Administration Services application (Administration Services).

In order for users to utilize the following formats, an administrator must configure Report Printing in Administration Services:

  • Microsoft Excel (XLS format)
  • PDF
  • Microsoft Word (RTF format)

309.name: CSV_SEPARATOR
309.helpText: Enter a column separator. If no value is entered, a comma or semicolon is used depending on your current NLS settings.

310.name: CSV_ENCLOSED_BY
310.helpText: Enter a delimiter character to delineate the starting and ending boundary of a data value. The default delimiter is double quotation marks.

311.name: DOWNLOAD_FILENAME
311.helpText: Enter the filename for the document when downloaded. Do not specify a file extension. The extension is added automatically. If you leave this attribute blank, the region name is used as the file name.

312.name: IR_LINK_COLUMN
312.helpText:
Select the link column type for this report.
If you select the link column, it always displays as the first column in the report and cannot be hidden by the user.

lovValues.helpText: The end user is directed to a page which shows the column values for the specified row. What and how columns display is governed by various report and column attributes.
The end user is directed to another page based on the target URL you enter.
The link column is not be displayed.

313.name: ALLOW_EXCLUDE_NULL_VALUES
313.helpText: Specify whether null columns are hidden on the Single Record View.

314.name: ALLOW_HIDE_EXTRA_COLUMNS
314.helpText: Specify whether only those columns currently displayed are displayed in the Single Record View. If you specify No then hidden report columns may also be shown on the Single Record View.

315.name: UNIQUELY_IDENTIFY_ROWS_BY
315.helpText: Select the type of column used to identify the current row when utilizing the link column. By default, ROWID is used to uniquely identify rows in a report. However, you can also utilize another column by selecting Unique Column.

316.name: UNIQUE_COLUMN
316.helpText:
Select the first column used to uniquely identify rows for this component.

ROWID is also included in the list of available columns for backwardd compatability.

Note: For an interactive report with the Link Column attribute set to Link to Single Row View, only a single unique column can be selected. Other components support the selection of up to three columns.

319.name: LINK_ICON
319.helpText: Enter the HTML to be used for the link. Use an image tag to display images, or pick from the list of default images. If not defined, #IMAGE_PREFIX#ws/small_page.gif is used.

32.name: CACHE_TIMEOUT
32.helpText: Select how long a cached page is valid. Subsequent page requests do not utilize the cached page if the timeout expires.

320.name: LINK_AUTHORIZATION_SCHEME
320.helpText: Select an authorization scheme to associate with the Link Column. This authorization scheme must evaluate to TRUE in order for the Link Column to be rendered in the report.

321.name: REPORT_ALIAS
321.helpText: Enter an alphanumeric alias for this interactive report region. The alias must be unique within the application. You can use an alias to reference an interactive report region in your custom API call. For example, you can write a function to return the INTERACTIVE_REPORT_ID by querying the ALIAS column in the APEX_APPLICATION_PAGE_IR view. Since the INTERACTIVE_REPORT_ID value can change when you export or import the application to different instance, referencing interactive report regions using an alias may be preferable.

322.name: REPORT_ID_ITEM
322.helpText:
Select a page or application item to store the region ID for this report.
This enables you to include the region ID, by referencing the value in this item, when defining a URL to navigate to a saved alternative or public report.

323.name: EMAIL_FROM_ADDRESS
323.helpText:
Enter a valid email address to use as the From address when sending email from this report. Emails are sent from this report for Downloads of type Email and for Subscriptions.

The value can be a literal string containing a valid email address or a static substitution reference defined in the application using substitution syntax. Using a page or application item substitution is NOT recommended because it only works in email download and causes any subscription emails to fail since these items can not be accessed outside of a valid session. Subscriptions are sent directly from the Application Express engine and not from a user session.

324.name: ICON_VIEW_ENABLED
324.helpText: Specify whether the Icon View is enabled. Selecting Yes adds a View Icons icon to the Search bar and enables users to access this view.

325.name: USE_CUSTOM_ICON_VIEW
325.helpText: Specify whether you wish to define a custom link for the Icon View. This option provides greater flexibility in defining the content of the Icon View, including the ability to utilize more than one column.

326.name: COLUMNS_PER_ROW
326.helpText: Select the number of icons to display per row in Icon View. A value of 5 displays 5 icons per row of the report.

327.name: ICON_VIEW_LINK_COLUMN
327.examples:
Examine the LINK column
select ename,
       job,
       'F?P=&APP_ID.:2:' || :APP_SESSION || '::::P2_ID:' || empno as link,
       '#IMAGE_PREFIX#menu/user_red_64.gif' as image
  from emp
327.helpText: Select the report column that returns the link target of the icon.

328.name: ICON_VIEW_IMAGE_SOURCE_COLUMN
328.examples:
Examine the IMAGE column
select ename,
       job,
       'F?P=&APP_ID.:2:' || :APP_SESSION || '::::P2_ID:' || empno as link,
       '#IMAGE_PREFIX#menu/user_red_64.gif' as image
  from emp
328.helpText: Select the report column that returns the image source.

329.name: ICON_VIEW_LABEL_COLUMN
329.examples:
Examine the ENAME column
select ename,
       job,
       'F?P=&APP_ID.:2:' || :APP_SESSION || '::::P2_ID:' || empno as link,
       '#IMAGE_PREFIX#menu/user_red_64.gif' as image
  from emp
329.helpText: Select the report column that returns the image label.

33.name: BROWSER_CACHE
33.helpText:
If the cache is enabled, the browser can save the contents of your application's pages in its cache, both in memory and on disk. If a user clicks the browser back button, the page typically loads from the cache, not from the server. If the cache is disabled, the browser is instructed to not save page content and requests it anew from the server.

Oracle recommends, from a security perspective, that the cache is disabled, so the browser does not store sensitive data and always requests pages if the URL changes. Otherwise, it may even be possible to go back in the browser history after a log out and see cached content of the former session. Disabling the browser cache prevents subtle back button issues with pages that use partial page refresh, such as interactive reports.

If this attribute is set to Disabled, Application Express sends the HTTP header cache-control: no-store which instructs the Browser to not cache the page contents on disk or in memory. If it is set to Application Default, the value at runtime is taken from the application's Browser Cache attribute.

Note: This feature requires modern browsers that support the HTTP header response variable cache-control.

330.name: ICON_VIEW_IMAGE_ATTRIBUTES
330.helpText: Enter the image attributes used for the HTML IMG tag.

331.name: ICON_VIEW_HTML_ALT_TEXT
331.helpText: Specify the HTML ALT text for the image.

332.name: ICON_VIEW_HTML_TITLE_TEXT
332.helpText: Specify the HTML TITLE tag for the image.

333.name: ICON_VIEW_CUSTOM_LINK
333.helpText: Enter the column link for the Icon View. Use #COLUMN_NAME# substitution strings for column names as required.

334.name: DETAIL_VIEW_ENABLED
334.helpText: Specify whether the Detail View is enabled. Selecting Yes adds a View Details icon to the Search bar which enables users to access this view.

335.name: DETAIL_VIEW_BEFORE_ROWS
335.helpText: Enter the HTML to be displayed before report rows.

336.name: DETAIL_VIEW_FOR_EACH_ROW
336.helpText: Enter the body for report rows in the Detail View. Use #COLUMN_NAME# substitution strings for column names and column labels.

337.name: DETAIL_VIEW_AFTER_ROWS
337.helpText: Enter the HTML to be displayed after report rows.

338.name: SHOW_FILTER
338.helpText: Specify whether end users can define filters on this report.

339.name: SHOW_SELECT_COLUMNS
339.helpText: Specify whether end users can use Select Columns in the Actions menu to change the columns displayed in this report. User can select (or show), deselect (or hide) and reorder multiple columns using this option.

340.name: SHOW_ROWS_PER_PAGE
340.helpText: Specify whether end users can change the number of rows displayed for this report.

341.name: SHOW_SORT
341.helpText: Specify whether end users can define sort columns for this report.

342.name: SHOW_CONTROL_BREAK
342.helpText: Specify whether end users can define control breaks for this report.

343.name: SHOW_HIGHLIGHT
343.helpText: Specify whether end users can define highlights for this report.

344.name: SHOW_COMPUTATION
344.helpText: Specify whether end users can define computational columns for this report.

345.name: SHOW_AGGREGATE
345.helpText: Specify whether end users can define aggregates for this report.

346.name: SHOW_CHART
346.helpText: Specify whether end users can define charts for this report.

347.name: SHOW_NOTIFY
347.helpText: Specify whether end users can define subscription settings for this report.

348.name: SHOW_GROUP_BY
348.helpText: Specify whether end,users can define group by break-downs for this report.

349.name: SHOW_PIVOT
349.helpText: Specify whether end users can define pivot break-downs for this report.

350.name: SHOW_FLASHBACK
350.helpText:
Specify whether end users can utilize flashback queries for this report.

Flashback queries utilize the Oracle Flashback Technology and Database Point-in-Time Recovery to view data as it existed at a previous point in time. Users can only query this data, but can not rewind any data changes. How far back in time they can successfully perform a flashback query is determined by when the redo log files were last switched within the Oracle database, as this technology utilizes the RMAN backup.

351.name: SHOW_RESET
351.helpText:
Specify whether end users can reset their reports from the Actions menu.

Reseting the report reverts all customizations made by the user, or specified by the calling URL, and displays the Primary Report.

352.name: SHOW_DOWNLOAD
352.helpText: Specify whether end users can download the report to one of the download formats specified.

353.name: SHOW_HELP
353.helpText:
Specify whether end users can invoke the built-in help modal dialog for interactive reports.

The help dialog only outlines those options available to the current user.

354.name: ALLOW_USERS_TO_SAVE_REPORTS
354.helpText:
Specify whether end users can save their current report definition as a Private report.

Private reports are displayed in a select list of available reports in the Search Bar, and are only displayed to the user who saved the report, providing they are authenticated. The option on the Actions menu is only available to authenticated users.

355.name: ALLOW_USERS_TO_SAVE_PUBLIC_REPORT
355.helpText:
Specify whether end users can save their current report definition as a Public report.

Public reports are displayed in a select list of available reports in the Search Bar, and are displayed to everyone. The option on the Actions menu is only available to authenticated users and is further restricted if you also populate the Save Public Report Authorization.

357.name: SHOW_FINDER_DROP_DOWN
357.helpText:
Specify whether the Finder drop down is included at the beginning of the Search field within the search bar.
The Finder drop down is a list of columns that enables users to limit their search to a specific column.

358.name: SHOW_DISPLAY_ROW_COUNT
358.helpText: Specify whether a separate drop down row selector is included within the search bar. You should not select both this attribute and Rows Per Page.

360.name: SHOW_SEARCH_TEXTBOX
360.helpText: Specify whether the search field is included within the search bar.

361.name: SHOW_ACTIONS_MENU
361.helpText: Specify whether the Actions menu is included within the Search Bar.

362.name: SHOW_REPORTS_SELECT_LIST
362.helpText:
Specify whether the Reports select list displays in the search bar.

The Reports select list only displays if a report, other than the primary report, is accessible to the user.

363.name: LINK_TARGET
363.helpText: Click the Target to invoke a modal dialog. You can enter a custom target to be called when the Link Column is clicked.

364.name: IR_SAVED_VISIBILITY
364.helpText: View the saved report category, which dictates where this report displays within the Reports select List. This attribute is view only and cannot be updated.

lovValues.helpText: Report saved by developers, that is displayed by default.
Subsequent report layouts saved by developers, that end users can select.
Report layouts saved by end users, that all other end users can select.
Report layouts saved by end users, that only the end user who saved it can select.

365.name: IR_SAVED_REPORT_ALIAS
365.helpText: Enter an alias for this saved report. Use this alias to define a more meaningful URL link to this specific saved report. This link can be used to link directly from elsewhere in the application.

366.name: LINK_EXAMPLE
366.helpText:
View the URL link for this saved report. This attribute is view only and cannot be updated.

This attribute enables you to quickly copy the displayed URL. This URL can be used to link directly to this particular saved report from anywhere else in the application.

367.name: RUN_PROCESS
367.helpText: Select the frequency that this process is executed.

lovValues.d: Once Per Session or When Reset

368.name: SUCCESS_MESSAGE
368.helpText: Enter the text to be displayed in the "Notification" area (defined as part of the page template), when this process completes successfully.

369.name: PROCESS_ERROR_DISPLAY_LOCATION
369.helpText: Select where this process error message displays, when the process fails to complete successfully.

lovValues.helpText: The process error message is displayed in the "Notification" area (defined as part of the page template)
The Process error message is displayed on the error page.

370.name: PROCESS_REGION
370.helpText: Select the Tabular Form region to associate with this process.

371.name: DA_EVENT
371.helpText: Select the appropriate dynamic action event from the available list.

372.name: IR_COLUMN_FILTER_LOV_SQL
372.helpText:
Enter a SQL query to be used in place of an automatically generated query that selects the distinct column values. This list of values displays when a user clicks on a column header.

The SQL query needs to return one column. If the query returns multiple columns, only the first column is used in the Column Filter list of values.

Entering a SQL query can improve performance in some reports.

373.name: LOV_TYPE
373.helpText: Select the list of values type.

lovValues.helpText: The list of values is based on a predefined list of values, defined in Shared Components.
The Dynamic list of values is based on the SQL Query you enter.
The Static list of values is based on the text value you enter.

lovValues.d: PL/SQL Function Body returning SQL Query
lovValues.helpText: The Dynamic list of values is based on the SQL Query returned by the entered PL/SQL Function Body you enter.

374.name: LOV_STATIC_VALUES
374.examples:
List sorted alphabetically, returning the numeric value
STATIC:Cow;1,Dog;2,Cat;3,Lion;4
List sorted in the same order they are specified, returning the numeric value
STATIC2:Cow;1,Dog;2,Cat;3,Lion;4
List sorted in the same order they are specified, returning the display value
STATIC2:Cow,Dog,Cat,Lion
374.helpText:
Enter the text for this static list of values.

If the text starts with STATIC:, the list values displays alphabetically. Alternatively, if the text starts with STATIC2:, the list values displays in the same order they are specified in the text.

375.name: TZ_DEPENDENT
375.helpText: Indicates whether or not this column is timezone aware.

376.name: PAGE_PROC_WS_PARM_ITEM
376.helpText: Enter the page or application item used as the source for this parameter. You can type in the name or pick from the list of available items.

377.name: PAGE_PROC_WS_PARM_SOURCE
377.helpText: Select the source for the parameter from the available list.

lovValues.helpText: Set to the value held in session state for the Item selected.
Set to the text entered into Static Value.
Set to the value returned from the PL/SQL Function Body entered.

379.name: PAGE_PROC_WS_PARM_VALUE
379.helpText: Enter the value for this parameter.

38.name: BUILD_OPTION
38.helpText:
Select a build option for this component.
Build options are predefined settings that determine whether or not components within an application are enabled.

380.name: CHART_TITLE
380.helpText: Specify a title to display at the top of the chart.

381.name: CHANGED_BY
381.helpText: Displays the user credentials of the developer who last updated this attribute.

382.name: CHANGED_ON
382.helpText: Displays when this attribute was last updated.

383.name: ALLOW_USERS_TO_PIVOT
383.helpText: Specify whether end user can define a pivot break-down within this report.

384.name: SOURCE_LIST
384.helpText: Select the source for this list.

385.name: SOURCE_BREADCRUMB
385.helpText: Select the breadcrumb list associated with this page.

386.name: LIST_TEMPLATE
386.helpText: Select the template utilized with this list.

387.name: BREADCRUMB_TEMPLATE
387.helpText: Select the breadcrumb template utilized with this breadcrumb.

389.name: LOV_NAME
389.helpText: Enter the name of this list of values.

39.name: INLINE_ERROR_NOTIFICATION_TEXT
39.helpText: Enter the error message displayed when an error occurs on this page. The error message is substituted for #NOTIFICATION_MESSAGE# in the page template.

390.name: HAS_GENERIC_COLUMNS
390.helpText:
Select whether column definitions are derived from the SQL query.
Doing this requires Application Express to parse the query.
If you do not want the query parsed at this time, use generic column names, which produces placeholder column definitions.

391.name: GENERIC_COLUMN_COUNT
391.helpText:
Enter the maximum number of generic report columns. Reports that use generic column names are parsed at runtime only, so the number of columns is not known when editing the report.

The maximum number of report columns should match the expected number of report columns. If the actual number is smaller, the report renders with the actual number of columns. However, if the actual number is higher than the maximum, then an error message shows at runtime.

392.name: PAGE_PROC_WS_PARM_FUNCTION
392.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL function body that returns a value used as the source for this parameter.

394.name: PAGE_PROC_WS_PARM_ITEMS
394.helpText:
Enter one or more page or application item used as the destination for this parameter. For multiple items, separate each item name with a comma.

You can type in the name or pick from the list of available items. If you pick from the list and there is already text entered, then a comma is placed at the end of the existing text, followed by the item name returned from the list.

395.name: COMPUTE_SUM
395.helpText:
For this column, specify whether the sum is computed and display at the end of the report.
When used with break columns, the total sum and the sum on each break displays.

396.name: COLUMN_WIDTH
396.helpText:
Specify the column width in pixels.
Use this attribute when displaying reports in a browser.
Note that setting the column width must be supported by the selected report template.

397.name: USE_AS_ROW_HEADER
397.helpText:
Specify whether this column also display in the Row Header. Including the column value can greatly improve accessibility for form fields rendered in a Tabular Form. When specified, this causes the Row Header to be used together with the Column Header to render the labels for the form fields in the Tabular Form, using this '<Column Header> : <Row Header>' format.

For example, suppose you have a Tabular Form on the EMP table and you define the ENAME column as the Row Header. For a row where ENAME is 'JONES,' the label for the Salary field in that row would be "Salary : JONES". This approach enables a screen reader user to be able to navigate by the Form fields in the Tabular Form and still maintain an understanding of which form fields relate to which row.

398.name: CLASSIC_REPORT_COLUMN_TYPE
398.helpText: Select the basis for this report column.

lovValues.helpText: Displays the column value.

lovValues.d: Plain Text (based on List of Values)
lovValues.helpText: Displays the value returned from the list of values specified.
Displays the column as a link.
Displays the column as an image.
Displays the column as a link to download the file.
Displays the column as a percentage graph. The value retrieved must be between 0 and 100.
Does not display the column, but it is referenceable.

399.name: DATE_PICKER_FORMAT_MASK
399.helpText: Select the format mask to apply to the date picker for this column.

4.name: COMMENTS
4.helpText: Enter any developer comments or notes here. These comments only display within Application Builder and never display when running the application.

40.name: HELP_TEXT
40.helpText:
Use this attribute to enter help text for the current page. Page level help supports shortcuts using the following syntax:

"SHORTCUT_NAME"

Page help text is not displayed by default. However, you can readily develop a help system that exposes this text.

400.name: RADIO_COLUMNS
400.helpText: Enter the number of columns to display for this radio group column.

402.name: SIMPLE_CHECKBOX_VALUES
402.helpText:
For the Simple Checkbox display type, enter either one value or two comma separated values. The first value is submitted if the checkbox is selected. The second value, if defined, is submitted if the checkbox is deselected.', p_examples => q'~
Submit Yes when selected and No when deselected
Yes,No

403.name: FORMATTING_CSS_CLASSES
403.examples:
Setting this attribute to fielddatabold results in the following HTML being generated
<span class="fielddatabold">Sample Data</span>
403.helpText:
Enter CSS classes to apply to this column's value. You can type in the CSS class or pick from the list of available items.

This class is included by default on all Application Express pages and has the definition of '.fielddatabold{font-size: 10pt; font-weight: bold; color: #000000;}'.

404.name: CSS_STYLE
404.examples:
Setting this attribute to color:#FF0000; changes the text color of the column to red and generates the following HTML
<span style="color:#FF0000">Sample Data</span>
404.helpText: Enter CSS styles to apply to this column's value. You can type in the CSS style or pick from the list of available items.

405.name: HIGHLIGHT_WORDS
405.helpText: Specify text strings to be highlighted in a report column. For multiple highlighted words, use a comma delimited list. You can also reference page or application items using &ITEM. syntax. For example, you can highlight strings entered into a search field.

406.name: COLUMN_SORT_SEQUENCE
406.helpText:
Select the sort sequence for this column.
Each column should have a unique sequence to correctly order the report output.

407.name: COLUMN_SORT_DIRECTION
407.helpText: Specify whether this column is sorted in Descending order. If not specified, the column is sorted in Ascending order (the default).

408.name: DISABLE_SORT_COLUMN
408.helpText: Specify whether this column can be used by the end user to sort the report.

409.name: INCLUDE_IN_EXPORT_PRINT
409.helpText: Specify whether this column is included when the report is exported to CSV or printed.

41.name: ERROR_HANDLING_FUNCTION
41.helpText:
Enter the name of the PL/SQL function called when an error occurs within the application. You can use this function to act on various error codes including those emanating from the Oracle database, and log such errors in a custom table you define if necessary. The function can include logic to modify the error message and display location, transforming Oracle database errors into user friendly messages. For example, you can capture a unique key violation on DEMO_CUSTOMERS and replace the ORA-00001 message with this text: Customer Name must be unique. Installing the Sample Database Application, from Packaged Applications, creates the SAMPLE_PKG package, which includes the demo_error_handling function. This sample error handling function includes extensive comments to make it easy for you to utilize as the basis for defining your own function.

The function name entered can reference a package function or stand alone function in the database. For example: 

log_apex_error

When referencing a database PL/SQL package or stand alone function, you can use the #OWNER# substitution string to reference the parsing schema of the current application. For example: 

#OWNER#.log_apex_error

If an error handling function is specified on a page then it is utilized, instead of this application level setting, for that page.

Error Handling Functions must implement the following interface: 

function <name of function> (
    p_error in apex_error.t_error )
    return apex_error.t_error_result

See the API Reference manual for a description of the package apex_error.

410.name: PRINT_COLUMN_WIDTH
410.helpText: Enter the column width used to size this column when the report is printed.

411.name: REPORT_TEMPLATE
411.helpText: Select the report template to use when displaying this report.

412.name: PCT_GRAPH_BACKGROUD_COLOR
412.examples:
Examples of major HTML color codes include -
  •   Black   #000000 RGB(0,0,0)
  •   Red   #FF0000 RGB(255,0,0)
  •   Yellow   #FFFF00 RGB(255,255,0)
  •   Lime   #00FF00 RGB(0,255,0)
  •   Green   #008000 RGB(0,128,0)
  •   Aqua   #00FFFF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Blue   #0000FF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Navy   #000080 RGB(0,0,128)
  •   White   #FFFFFF RGB(255,255,255)
412.helpText:
Enter the color used for the background of this graph. The color is specified using hexadecimal (hex) notation, RGB color codes, or HTML color names.
